Yes, but something like 100 million Americans have diabetes, 70 million have High Blood Pressure, 25 million have asthma.

I'm more than willing to bet that the overwhelming majority of the US population over 30 has one of their other diseases.  I'm also willing to bet that Italy has the same condition.

If you dip a toe in the seas around Britain, Ireland, Norway, Sweden, etc, etc you'll find it rather different to what the travel agents sell as "Mediterranean".  Eat out in Normandy and you'll not find much in the way of trendy low fat options.

FWIW My impression is that the key to Mediterranean health isn't the diet, it's not giving a flyer about anything.  Stress only affects people who care.

That whole "Mediterranean diet" schtick was developed because they were looking at hard working peasant farmers, most of whom didn't get old enough to develop heart disease and other problems of the aging, and who burned off the calories they did take in with physical labor.

It was always a crock of shit, and was being called out as such by people with half a brain half a century ago when it first started getting promoted.
